context: We utilized SuperQ adsorbent resin in this study, and the other groups used carbon filters in a closed-loop-stripping system. Both methods are widely used and accepted, however these differences do point out the need to exercise caution in data interpretation, especially in light of any negative results when analyzing volatile profiles. In addition to its role as a potential attractant to natural enemies of herbivores, volatile (E)-β-ocimene is also active in plant-plant signaling. Uninfested lima bean plants perceive volatiles, including (E)-β-ocimene, emitted by T. urticae-injured plants and this elicits ethylene release and activation of genes involved in defense. The (E)-β-ocimene isomer, allo-ocimene, from Arabidopsis has also been shown to be active in eliciting defense responses and fungal resistance in neighboring plants. The full implications of the defensive roles of (E)-β-ocimene in M. truncatula have yet to be determined. Expression of an M. truncatula terpene synthase-encoding cDNA in E. coli has led to its functional identification as (E)-β-ocimene synthase.

llm_generation.summary: (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene, specifically the (E)-β-ocimene isomer, is identified as a volatile substance that plays a role in plant signaling and defense mechanisms. It is emitted by plants in response to herbivore damage, influencing neighboring plants' defense responses. This highlights the functional significance of (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene as a volatile compound involved in ecological interactions.
